channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: North Korea Acts to Stop U.N. Resolution on Rights
item.description: On the eve of a United Nations vote that could hold leaders of North Korea accountable for rights violations, diplomats said that they had rarely seen such frenetic action from the nation.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Qatar: Ambassadors to Return
item.description: Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain said Monday that they would reinstate their ambassadors to Qatar after withdrawing them eight months ago.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Miss Honduras Is Target of Search
item.description: The beauty queen and her sister were last seen getting into a car to go to a party on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: President of Colombia Halts Peace Talks With Rebels After General Is Seized
item.description: Describing what occurred as a kidnapping, President Juan Manuel Santos said that he had directed the country’s peace negotiators not to travel to Havana for a new round of talks with the guerrillas.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Army Press Office/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Bear That Became the Symbol of a Movement Dies
item.description: Oliver, as the bear was called, was rescued in 2010 by the advocacy group Animals Asia after spending 30 years in bear-bile farms. His dramatic journey to a new life was captured in the documentary “Cages of Shame.”
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: Oliver was a brown bear who was rescued in 2010 by the advocacy group Animals Asia from a bile farm in the province of Shandong, along with nine other bears.

item.title: Setting Usual Caution Aside, Merkel Issues a Stern Rebuke to Russia
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel, in a speech, asked whether Russia’s annexation of Crimea and moves in eastern Ukraine meant a return to the times when Moscow decided the fate of its near neighbors.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: The Russian Embassy in Warsaw on Monday. Russian and Polish officials confirmed that they have carried out tit-for-tat diplomatic expulsions.

item.title: Coal Rush in India Could Tip Balance on Climate Change
item.description: The country has a voracious and growing demand for energy, and officials see coal as the best way forward. However, experts predict dire consequences.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers last month at a strip mine in Jharkhand, India. India’s coal rush could push the world past the brink of irreversible climate change, with India among the worst affected countries, scientists say.

item.title: World Briefing: Sudan: Peace Talks Adjourn
item.description: Talks between the Sudanese government and a rebel group adjourned in Ethiopia on Monday, to be reconvened at a date yet to be determined.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: Global Number of Youths Is Highest Ever, U.N. Reports
item.description: A United Nations report said the fate of the world’s adolescent population depended on governments’ ability to provide health care, education and jobs.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Egypt Will Expand Its Security Zone Near Gaza Strip
item.description: The discovery of smuggling tunnels will lead to the doubling of a secured buffer zone in the border town of Rafah, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MERNA THOMAS
item.media:description: Former residents gathered around remains of buildings destroyed by the Egyptian military on Nov. 4 in the border town of Rafah.

item.title: Doctor Being Treated for Ebola in Omaha Dies
item.description: Dr. Martin Salia, who died on Monday of Ebola, was two weeks into his illness and presented a steep challenge for treatment.
item.dc:creator: By ABBY GOODNOUGH and TOMMY TRENCHARD
item.media:credit: Mike Dubose/United Methodist, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Dr. Martin Salia at United Methodist Kissy Hospital outside Freetown, Sierra Leone.

item.title: World Briefing: Millions Forced to Live as Slaves, a Human Rights Group Reports
item.description: Almost 36 million people are living as slaves across the globe, according to a human rights group, with India having the largest number over all and Mauritania the highest percentage of its population.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: A Master of Memory in India Credits Meditation for His Brainy Feats
item.description: A guru’s protégé memorizes objects by the hundreds before admiring crowds.
item.dc:creator: By MAX BEARAK
item.media:credit: Graham Crouch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Munishri Ajitchandrasagarji, a Jain monk who captivates audiences with his ability to memorize hundreds of random items in sequence.

item.title: From an Egyptian-American Prisoner on Hunger Strike in Cairo, a Letter Home
item.description: Mohamed Soltan, who has been incarcerated for more than a year since his arrest at a street protest, wrote to his family on his 27th birthday.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Church of England Approves Plan Allowing Female Bishops
item.description: The archbishop of Canterbury predicted that half of the church’s bishops could be women within a decade.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Members of the Anglican clergy voting in London on Monday for a historic change.

item.title: E.U. to Toughen Sanctions on Ukrainian Separatists, but Not Russia
item.description: The bloc decided to widen sanctions on individuals in Ukraine while pushing for a diplomatic solution to Russia’s involvement there.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: In India, Growth Breeds Waste
item.description: Indians are getting dirtier as they get richer, but cleaning up is still someone else's job.
item.dc:creator: By JERRY PINTO

item.title: Hong Kong Warns It May Clear Part of a Protest Site
item.description: The police were said to be ready to help court bailiffs enforce an injunction ordering demonstrators to stop congregating around a tower near government headquarters.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Police officers near a barricade set up by pro-democracy protesters in the Mong Kok district of Hong Kong on Monday.

item.title: International Education: M.I.T. Settles In for Long Haul in Singapore
item.description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has a long-term relationship in Singapore that involves managing five labs with 40 Ph.D. and post-doc researchers.
item.dc:creator: By JANE A. PETERSON
item.media:description: Singapore-M.I.T. Alliance for Research and Technology, or Smart, is a team of professors that manages five laboratories paid for by the Singapore government.

item.title: Avian Flu Detected in the Netherlands and Britain
item.description: It was not clear if the outbreaks at poultry farms in the two countries were linked, but a British veterinary official said wild birds may have carried the disease.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: People in protective clothing on Monday at a farm in East Yorkshire in the north of England, where a case of bird flu had been found in ducks.

item.title: Briton and Frenchman Tentatively Identified in Islamic State Execution Video
item.description: French officials and the father of a missing British man tentatively identified two European men among those who executed Peter Kassig, an American aid worker, in a video released by the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:description: An image taken from a propaganda video released by the Islamic State militant group shows a man believed to be Maxime Hauchard, a French citizen.

item.title: Pope Francis Confirms U.S. Visit for Next Year
item.description: The trip, his first to the country as pontiff, will include an international gathering in Philadelphia. He is also expected to make a stop in New York.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: It was announced that Pope Francis will visit the United States in 2015.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Newspaper Calls on Chinese Academics to Cut the Criticism
item.description: A Chinese newspaper’s look into university professors’ criticism of China has triggered an online debate about academic freedom and whether scholars have a patriotic duty to refrain from criticizing the country and its political system.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Keith Bedford for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students listening to a lecture at Sanya College, Hainan Province. A Liaoning Daily investigation concluded that many professors were not supportive enough of China's political system.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Afghans Aren't Giving Up
item.description: Despite the violence and corruption, many say their new president has inspired hope that things will change.
item.dc:creator: By THEODORE L. ELIOT Jr. and KARL F. INDERFURTH

item.title: Burkina Faso Names Ex-Diplomat as Interim Leader
item.description: Michel Kafando, 72, was chosen more than two weeks after the ouster of President Blaise Compaoré, who fled the country in the face of mass protests.
item.dc:creator: By HERVÉ TAOKO and ALAN COWELL
